title: If there is a star older than the universe, does that mean that before its birth, the universe was not a singularity? How is it even possible? - Quora

response.answer_text: the term you are looking for is “error bar” if you are a *true* scientist, the first thing you learn is what the meaning of an error bar is. you only perceive the world through measurements (even simple looking, hearing, smelling etc. are deep down just measurements). every measurement has a kind of tolerance: it doesn’t measure some precise single values but always ranges of values. sometimes that ranges are quite small so you can safely ignore them and call them “single values”. sometimes that ranges are quite big and ignoring them gives you completly wrong results. so if you ask a *real* scientist for the value of some measurement, he/she will *always* tell you something like X +/- Y (where hopefully Y is much smaller then X). example: you ask the scientist what the mass of that stone is and he/she will tell you “0.5 kg +/- 0.00005” means: the mass can be everywhere between 0.49995 and 0.500005 kg. of course he/she could use a more precise scale to produce a smaller error bar but this would be more expensive and most often more precise measurements simply are not necessary. ok - the age of the universe is a quite important value in all of cosmology. measureing it to a very high precision is top priority. there are expensive satellites which where only launched specifically for that measurement. then some folks found by sheer chance a star which looks by the first rough measurement quite old. and then you have some reporters which don’t understand what an error bar is and tell you that scientists found a star which is older then the universe. ok - let’s look at the actual data: age of the universe: 13.798 mrd years +/- 0.037 age of the oldest known star “HD 140283”: 14.5 mrd years +/- 0.8 and of course: the first one is a quite exact measurement, the second one is a rough estimate based on some assumptions.. if you only look at the “big” value (like some reporters) you think that this star is much older than the universe. if you know what an error bar is, this star is clearly a very old star (most likely one of the first of the second generation of stars) but perfectly consistent with current cosmology.

If there is a star older than the universe, does that mean that before its birth, the universe was not a singularity? If someone CLAIMS to have discovered a star older than age generally agreed age of the universe then either; Their data is wrong or mis-interpreted, orThe generally agreed age of the universe is wrong, orSome combination of the two.A data set like the generally agreed age of the universe does move a littles as new pieces of information gradually get accepted and incorporated. How is it even possible? It’s possible because people make claims about all sorts of things. And an unusual or controversial claims make the news and get publicity for everyone. So it happens quite a lot. Generally, these claims are quietly retracted some time later but occasionally they become accepted as part of reality.
